title: rustc crashes with a type mismatch inside closure

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

body:
``` rust
use std::io::Read;

fn read_contents(path: &str) -> String {
    let mut buf = Vec::new();
    match std::fs::File::open(path).and_then(|x| x.read_to_string(&mut buf)) {
        Ok(x)  => x,
        Err(_) => String::new(),
    }
}

fn main() {}
```

The above snipped crashes rustc 1.9.0. `buf` is a `Vec<?>`, but read_to_string expects a `String`. The error message is:

`thread 'rustc' panicked at 'index out of bounds: the len is 16 but the index is 18', src/libcollections/vec.rs:1166`

The crash still occurs even if explicit type annotations are added to the closure, although the values for len and index in the error message above is different. It does not happen, however, if `Vec::new()` is replaced with `Vec::<u8>::new()`, so the bug is probably triggered when rustc tries to derive that type argument.

Verbose version information (ArchLinux's rust-1:1.9.0-1):

```
rustc 1.9.0
binary: rustc
commit-hash: unknown
commit-date: unknown
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.9.0
```

The compiler backtrace is:
